      First report on the pharmacokinetic profile of nimbolide, a novel anticancer agent in oral and intravenous administrated rats by LC/MS method
      Baira, Shandilya Mahamuni; Khurana, Amit; Somagoni, Jaganmohan; Srinivas, R.; Godugu, Chandraiah; Talluri, M. V. N. Kumar
      Journal of Chromatography B: Analytical Technologies in the Biomedical and Life Sciences (2018), 1092 (), 191-198CODEN: JCBAAI; ISSN:1570-0232. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Nimbolide is a novel, natural compd. with promising potential as a drug candidate for anticancer activity. It is isolated from the Indian traditional medicinal plant Azadirachta indica popularly known as neem. The present study was undertaken to explore the oral bioavailability and pharmacokinetic characteristics of nimbolide in rats using the LC/QTOF/MS method. A simple protein pptn. method using acetonitrile was employed for extg. nimbolide from rat plasma. The chromatog. sepn. of nimbolide and the internal std. (regorafenib) was attained on an Aquity BEH C18 column (100Ã2.1mm, 2.7Î¼m), using ACN and 0.1% of formic acid in water as mobile phase components in a gradient elution mode at a flow rate of 0.45mL/min over a short run time of 4min. A mass detection was carried out using target ions of [M+H]+ at m/z 467.2074 for nimbolide and m/z 483.0847 for the internal std. The LC/MS method was validated and all the parameters were found well within the specified limits. The calibration curve was constructed in the range of 1-1000ng/mL. The method shows good accuracy (91.66-97.12%) and precision (intra 2.21-6.92% CV and inter-day 2.56-4.62% CV). This developed LC/MS method was effectively applied to the pharmacokinetic study of nimbolide upon oral and i.v. administration in rats. In concordance with its physicochem. properties and high lipophilicity, we found that it shows poor oral absorption at different doses (10, 30 and 50mg/kg). As expected, higher plasma levels were obsd. upon i.v. (10mg/kg) administration. This method can be extended for evaluation of drug interaction and drug metab. in rats as well as in humans. Moreover, our rapid and sensitive method may cater the need to accelerate the preclin. formulation development and lead optimization for future drug development of this potent anticancer agent. Further, our oral bioavailability studies demonstrated that nimbolide possesses poor oral absorption, which could be the probable reason for the delay in therapeutic translation of this promising agent for clin. use.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtFCqsb7E&md5=a59323ce4452b99ecc9e7b5bbbd102db
    93. 93
      Wang, L.; Phan, D. K.; Syn, N.; Xiang, X.; Song, H.; Thuya, W. L.; Yang, S.; Wong, A. L.; Kumar, A. P.; Yong, W. P.; Sethi, G.; Ho, P. C.; Goh, B. C. A sensitive liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method for the determination of nimbolide in mouse serum: Application to a preclinical pharmacokinetics study. Pharmaceutics 2018, 10, 123, Â DOI: 10.3390/pharmaceutics10030123
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      93
      A sensitive liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method for the determination of nimbolide in mouse serum: application to a preclinical pharmacokinetics study
      Wang, Lingzhi; Phan, Do-Dang Khoa; Syn, Nicholas; Xiang, Xiaoqiang; Song, Hongyan; Thuya, Win Lwin; Yang, Shili; Wong, Andrea Li-Ann; Id, Alan Prem Kumar; Yong, Wei Peng; Sethi, Gautam; Ho, Paul Chi-Lui; Goh, Boon Cher
      Pharmaceutics (2018), 10 (3), 123CODEN: PHARK5; ISSN:1999-4923. (MDPI AG)
      A sensitive and robust liq. chromatog.-tandem mass spectrometric (LC-MS/MS) method was developed and validated for the detn. of nimbolide in mouse serum. Exemestane was used as the internal std. (IS). Here, we employed acetonitrile-based protein pptn. (PPT) for serum sample prepn., and performed chromatog. sepn. using an ODS Hypersil C18 column (100 mm Ã 2.1 mm, 5 Î¼m) with gradient elution (0.1% formic acid in water vs 100% acetonitrile). The run time was 6 min. Instrumental anal. was performed by electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (ESI-MS/MS) in the multiple-reaction monitoring (MRM) under pos. mode. A good linear calibration was achieved in the 5-1000 ng/mL range. The intra- and inter-day precisions for nimbolide were â¤12.6% and â¤13.9% resp. Intra-day accuracy ranged from 96.9-109.3%, while inter-day accuracy ranged from 94.3-110.2%. The matrix effect of nimbolide, detected but consistent at low and high concns., do not affect linearity of std. curve. In conclusion, we have developed and validated a sensitive anal. method for detn. of a novel natural compd. nimbolide in mouse serum, and it has been successfully applied to our preclin. study in investigating the pharmacokinetic properties of nimbolide, which could greatly facilitate the preclin. development of the promising lead compd. for anticancer therapy.

      Glinsukon, T.; Somjaree, R.; Piyachaturawat, P.; Thebtaranonth, Y. Acute toxicity of nimbolide and nimbic acid in mice, rats and hamsters. Toxicol. Lett. 1986, 30, 159â 166, Â DOI: 10.1016/0378-4274(86)90098-6
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      95
      Acute toxicity of nimbolide and nimbic acid in mice, rats and hamsters
      Glinsukon, Thirayudh; Somjaree, Rosenee; Piyachaturawat, Pawinee; Thebtaranonth, Yodhathai
      Toxicology Letters (1986), 30 (2), 159-66CODEN: TOLED5; ISSN:0378-4274.
      Nimbolide (I) [25990-37-8] and nimbic acid (II) [11030-74-3] are toxic to mice only when given i.p. and i.v. but they are less toxic to rats and hamsters than to mice. The LD50 values of a single i.p. administration of nimbolide in adult male and female and weanling mice were 225, 280, and 240 mg/kg, resp., and its i.v. LD50 value was only 24 mg/kg in adult male mice. No fatality was obsd. when nimbolide was given orally, i.m. and s.c. to adult male mice. Estd. LD50 values of nimbolide in rats and hamsters were somewhat greater than 600 and 500 mg/kg, resp. Twelve-23 h after i.p. administration of an LD, most animals had died of possible dysfunctions in kidneys (tubular necrosis), small intestine hemorrhagic necrosis), pancreas (acinar cell necrosis), and liver (mild fatty infiltration and focal necrosis). In contrast, mice and rats given an LD of nimbolide (i.v.) died of a marked and sudden drop in arterial blood pressure and respiratory paralysis within about 1-18 min. Nimbic acid was less toxic than nimbolide to mice, with an i.v. LD50 value of 265 mg/kg and i.p. and oral LD50 values >600 mg/kg. The possible cause of death induced by nimbic acid may be similar to that by nimbolide given i.v. and this is sudden hypotensive shock.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      96
      The mutagenicities of seven coumarin derivatives and a furan derivative (nimbolide) isolated from three medicinal plants
      Uwaifo, Anthony O.
      Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health (1984), 13 (4-6), 521-30CODEN: JTEHD6; ISSN:0098-4108.
      Seven coumarin derivs. imperatorin (I, R=CH2C:CMe2) [482-44-0], heraclenin (I, R= dimethyloxiranylmethyl) [2880-49-1], xanthotoxin (I, R = Me) [298-81-7], marmesin (II, R1 = CMe2OH; R2 = R3 = H) [13849-08-6], chalepin (II, R1 = CMe2OH, R2=H, R3 = CMe2CH:CH2) [13164-04-0], oxypeucedanin [26091-73-6], and esculin (III) [531-75-9] and a furan deriv. nimbolide (IV) [25990-37-8] were screened with Ames tester strains (TA 92, 94, 97, 98, 100, and 102). Marmesin and imperatorin were mutagenic in all tester strains except TA 94 and 102. The mutagenicity potencies of marmesin and imperatorin were 20 and 0.2, resp. Mutagenicity was highest in TA98 and 100 in both compds. Marmesin was optimally mutagenic at 1.04 Î¼g, and imperatorin at 30.0 Î¼g. Microsomal activation was not required for mutagenicity in both compds.

      Suttiarporn, P.; Choommongkol, V. Microwave-assisted improved extraction and purification of anticancer nimbolide from Azadirachta indica (Neem) leaves. Molecules 2020, 25, 2913, Â DOI: 10.3390/molecules25122913

      99
      Microwave-assisted improved extraction and purification of anticancer nimbolide from Azadirachta indica (Neem) leaves
      Suttiarporn, Panawan; Choommongkol, Vachira
      Molecules (2020), 25 (12), 2913CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
      Nimbolide, a limonoid present in leaves of the neem tree (Azadirachta indica), is an anticancer compd. against a panel of human cancer cell lines. The rapid process of extn. and purifn. of the nimbolide from the leaves of neem tree through microwave-assisted extn. (MAE) coupled with a chromatog. technique was accomplished. The crude with a max. content of nimbolide could be recovered from neem leaves through MAE. By using three-factors, three-level Box-Behnken design of response surface methodol. (RSM), the optimal conditions for nimbolide extn. (R2 = 0.9019) were solid/liq. ratio 1:16 g/mL, microwave power 280 W, and extn. time 22 min. The enriched ext. was further purified by a preparative thin-layer chromatog. (PTLC), where nimbolide was obtained as 0.0336 g (0.67% yield, purity over 98%) with Et acetate/hexane = 4:6 in 3.0 h. Structural elucidation was performed through spectroscopic techniques, including FT-IR, 1H, and 13C-NMR. This method was simple and had a good potential for the purifn. of bioactive compds. from a natural product.

      Patra, A.; Satpathy, S.; Hussain, M. D. Nanodelivery and anticancer effect of a limonoid, nimbolide, in breast and pancreatic cancer cells. Int. J. Nanomed. 2019, 14, 8095â 8104, Â DOI: 10.2147/IJN.S208540
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      100
      Nanodelivery and anticancer effect of a limonoid, nimbolide, in breast and pancreatic cancer cells
      Patra, Arjun; Satpathy, Swaha; Hussain, Muhammad Delwar
      International Journal of Nanomedicine (2019), 14 (), 8095-8104CODEN: IJNNHQ; ISSN:1178-2013. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
      Introduction: Nimbolide (Nim), a limonoid obtained from the neem tree, Azadirachta indica, has several pharmacol. properties, including anticancer effects in different type of cancers. No drug-delivery system has been reported for enhancing the therapeutic application of this novel hydrophobic mol. Methods: In the present research, poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) nanoparticles of Nim (Nim-nano) were formulated by nanopptn., characterized for physicochem. properties, and screened for anticancer potential in breast (MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231) and pancreatic (AsPC-1) cancer cell lines. Results: The Nim-nano had a particle size of 183.73 Â± 2.22 nm and 221.20 Â± 11.03 nm before and after lyophilization, resp. Cryoprotectants (mannitol and sucrose) significantly inhibited growth in particle size due to lyophilization. The Î¶-potential of the Nim-nano was -22.40 Â± 4.40 mV. Drug loading and encapsulation efficiency of Nim-nano were 5.25% Â± 1.12% and 55.67% Â± 12.42%, resp. The Nim-nano exhibited sustained release of Nim for more than 6 days in PBS (pH 7.4) and showed two- to three-fold enhanced cytotoxicity in breast and pancreatic cancer cell lines compared with free Nim. Conclusion: The Nim-nano formulation has great potential for treatment of cancers, such as pancreatic and breast cancer. Further, the PLGA-polymer surface can be modified by conjugation with polyethylene glycol, receptor-binding ligands (eg, folic acid), and other that which may lead to targeted delivery of Nim in the treatment of cancer.

      101
      iRGD conjugated nimbolide liposomes protect against endotoxin induced acute respiratory distress syndrome
      Pooladanda, Venkatesh; Thatikonda, Sowjanya; Sunnapu, Omprakash; Tiwary, Shristy; Vemula, Praveen Kumar; Talluri, M. V. N. Kumar; Godugu, Chandraiah
      Nanomedicine (New York, NY, United States) (2021), 33 (), 102351CODEN: NANOBF; ISSN:1549-9634. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a deadly respiratory illness assocd. with refractory hypoxemia and pulmonary edema. The recent pandemic outbreak of COVID-19 is assocd. with severe pneumonia and inflammatory cytokine storm in the lungs. The anti-inflammatory phytomedicine nimbolide (NIM) may not be feasible for clin. translation due to poor pharmacokinetic properties and lack of suitable delivery systems. To overcome these barriers, we have developed nimbolide liposomes conjugated with iRGD peptide (iRGD-NIMLip) for targeting lung inflammation. It was obsd. that iRGD-NIMLip treatment significantly inhibited oxidative stress and cytokine storm compared to nimbolide free-drug (f-NIM), nimbolide liposomes (NIMLip), and exhibited superior activity compared to dexamethasone (DEX). IRGD-NIMLip abrogated the LPS induced p65 NF-ÎºB, Akt, MAPK, Integrin Î²3 and Î²5, STAT3, and DNMT1 expression. Collectively, our results demonstrate that iRGD-NIMLip could be a promising novel drug delivery system to target severe pathol. consequences obsd. in ARDS and COVID-19 assocd. cytokine storm.

      Tong, B.; Spradlin, J. N.; Novaes, L. F. T.; Zhang, E.; Hu, X.; Moeller, M.; Brittain, S. M.; McGregor, L. M.; McKenna, J. M.; Tallarico, J. A.; Schirle, M.; Maimone, T. J.; Nomura, D. K. A nimbolide-based kinase degrader preferentially degrades oncogenic BCR-ABL. ACS Chem. Biol. 2020, 15, 1788â 1794, Â DOI: 10.1021/acschembio.0c00348
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      102
      A Nimbolide-Based Kinase Degrader Preferentially Degrades Oncogenic BCR-ABL
      Tong, Bingqi; Spradlin, Jessica N.; Novaes, Luiz F. T.; Zhang, Erika; Hu, Xirui; Moeller, Malte; Brittain, Scott M.; McGregor, Lynn M.; McKenna, Jeffrey M.; Tallarico, John A.; Schirle, Markus; Maimone, Thomas J.; Nomura, Daniel K.
      ACS Chemical Biology (2020), 15 (7), 1788-1794CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      Targeted protein degrdn. (TPD) and proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) have arisen as powerful therapeutic modalities for degrading specific proteins in a proteasome-dependent manner. However, a major limitation of TPD is the lack of E3 ligase recruiters. Recently, we discovered the natural product nimbolide as a covalent recruiter for the E3 ligase RNF114. Here, we show the broader utility of nimbolide as an E3 ligase recruiter for TPD applications. We demonstrate that a PROTAC linking nimbolide to the kinase and BCR-ABL fusion oncogene inhibitor dasatinib, BT1, selectively degrades BCR-ABL over c-ABL in leukemia cancer cells, compared to previously reported cereblon or VHL-recruiting BCR-ABL degraders that show opposite selectivity or, in some cases, inactivity. Thus, we further establish nimbolide as an addnl. general E3 ligase recruiter for PROTACs, and we demonstrate the importance of expanding upon the arsenal of E3 ligase recruiters, as such mols. confer differing selectivity for the degrdn. of neo-substrate proteins.

Chemoproteomics-enabled discovery of covalent RNF114-based degraders that mimic natural product function. Cell Chem. Biol. 2021, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.chembiol.2021.01.005
      [Crossref], [PubMed],Â Google Scholar

    104. 104
      Bundela, S.; Sharma, A.; Bisen, P. S. Potential compounds for oral cancer treatment: Resveratrol, nimbolide, lovastatin, bortezomib, vorinostat, berberine, pterostilbene, deguelin, andrographolide, and colchicine. PLoS One 2015, 10, e0141719, Â DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0141719
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      104
      Potential compounds for oral cancer treatment: resveratrol, nimbolide, lovastatin, bortezomib, vorinostat, berberine, pterostilbene, deguelin, andrographolide, and colchicines
      Bundela, Saurabh; Sharma, Anjana; Bisen, Prakash S.
      PLoS One (2015), 10 (11), e0141719/1-e0141719/31CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
      Oral cancer is one of the main causes of cancer-related deaths in South-Asian countries. There are very limited treatment options available for oral cancer. Research endeavors focused on discovery and development of novel therapies for oral cancer, is necessary to control the ever rising oral cancer related mortalities. We mined the large pool of compds. from the publicly available compd. databases, to identify potential therapeutic compds. for oral cancer. Over 84 million compds. were screened for the possible anti-cancer activity by custom build SVM classifier. The mol. targets of the predicted anti-cancer compds. were mined from reliable sources like exptl. bioassays studies assocd. with the compd., and from protein-compd. interaction databases. Therapeutic compds. from DrugBank, and a list of natural anti-cancer compds. derived from literature mining of published studies, were used for building partial least squares regression model. The regression model thus built, was used for the estn. of oral cancer sp. wt.s based on the mol. targets. These wts. were used to compute scores for screening the predicted anti-cancer compds. for their potential to treat oral cancer. The list of potential compds. was annotated with corresponding physicochem. properties, cancer specific bioactivity evidences, and literature evidences. In all, 288 compds. with the potential to treat oral cancer were identified in the current study. The majority of the compds. in this list are natural products, which are well-tolerated and have minimal side-effects compared to the synthetic counterparts. Some of the potential therapeutic compds. identified in the current study are resveratrol, nimbolide, lovastatin, bortezomib, vorinostat, berberine, pterostilbene, deguelin, andrographolide, and colchicine.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvV2iu7rE&md5=f085b521e37cfd4fa5c5e04fd4b54f6d

      Agrawal, S.; Popli, D. B.; Sircar, K.; Chowdhry, A. A review of the anticancer activity of Azadirachta indica (Neem) in oral cancer. J. Oral Biol. Craniofac. Res. 2020, 10, 206â 209, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.jobcr.2020.04.007
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      105
      A review of the anticancer activity of Azadirachta indica (Neem) in oral cancer
      Agrawal Shikha; Bablani Popli Deepika; Sircar Keya; Chowdhry Aman
      Journal of oral biology and craniofacial research (2020), 10 (2), 206-209 ISSN:2212-4268.
      Background: Azadirachta indica (neem), belongs to the family of Meliaceae plants, is found in the Indian subcontinent. The neem tree is colloquially referred to as the village pharmacy due to its array of biological properties. Every part of the neem tree like its bark, leaves, sap, fruit, seeds, and twigs find a multitude of uses. It is customary to use them for management of skin diseases and various other infections.The anticancer properties of neem have been studied in the past and these include its ability to modulate the tumour environment, increase the cytotoxic ability of host monocytes and suppress the proliferation of tumour cells. The present review was conducted with the objective of scrutinizing and assimilating data about the usefulness Azadirachta indica in oral cancer from all the previously done work. Material and methods: A planned review was conducted of all the studies that investigated the role of Azadirachta indica in oral cancer. Literature search was carried out using PubMed, Scopus and Google scholar databases. In addition to electronic searching, hand searching, cross referencing and various internet engines were also used to collect data. The articles were perused and articles not pertinent to our search were omitted. Results and conclusion: The anticancer properties of neem were evaluated and the active constituents of neem have been demonstrated to unequivocally have preventive and therapeutic potential against oral cancer. Although, greater exploration of the anticancer properties of neem are required in order to effectively integrate it into the routine management of oral cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB38rltV2ruw%253D%253D&md5=a84da9f9f07de63ce5f4edc81cc265c4
    106. 106
      Ramsay, R. R.; Popovic-Nikolic, M. R.; Nikolic, K.; Uliassi, E.; Bolognesi, M. L. A perspective on multi-target drug discovery and design for complex diseases. Clin. Transl. Med. 2018, 7, 3, Â DOI: 10.1186/s40169-017-0181-2
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      106
      A perspective on multi-target drug discovery and design for complex diseases
      Ramsay Rona R; Popovic-Nikolic Marija R; Nikolic Katarina; Uliassi Elisa; Bolognesi Maria Laura
      Clinical and translational medicine (2018), 7 (1), 3 ISSN:2001-1326.
      Diseases of infection, of neurodegeneration (such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases), and of malignancy (cancers) have complex and varied causative factors. Modern drug discovery has the power to identify potential modulators for multiple targets from millions of compounds. Computational approaches allow the determination of the association of each compound with its target before chemical synthesis and biological testing is done. These approaches depend on the prior identification of clinically and biologically validated targets. This Perspective will focus on the molecular and computational approaches that underpin drug design by medicinal chemists to promote understanding and collaboration with clinical scientists.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MvhsVaiug%253D%253D&md5=5b05a73a3bbc955c77b9b2df93deb946

        Ferlay, J.; Colombet, M.; Soerjomataram, I.; Mathers, C.; Parkin, D. M.; PiÃ±eros, M.; Znaor, A.; Bray, F. Estimating the global cancer incidence and mortality in 2018: GLOBOCAN sources and methods. Int. J. Cancer 2019, 144, 1941â 1953, Â DOI: 10.1002/ijc.31937
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        1
        Estimating the global cancer incidence and mortality in 2018: GLOBOCAN sources and methods
        Ferlay, J.; Colombet, M.; Soerjomataram, I.; Mathers, C.; Parkin, D. M.; Pineros, M.; Znaor, A.; Bray, F.
        International Journal of Cancer (2019), 144 (8), 1941-1953CODEN: IJCNAW; ISSN:0020-7136. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        Ests. of the worldwide incidence and mortality from 36 cancers and for all cancers combined for the year 2018 are now available in the GLOBOCAN 2018 database, compiled and disseminated by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). This paper reviews the sources and methods used in compiling the cancer statistics in 185 countries. The validity of the national ests. depends upon the representativeness of the source information, and to take into account possible sources of bias, uncertainty intervals are now provided for the estd. sex- and site-specific all-ages no. of new cancer cases and cancer deaths. We briefly describe the key results globally and by world region. There were an estd. 18.1 million (95% UI: 17.5-18.7 million) new cases of cancer (17 million excluding non-melanoma skin cancer) and 9.6 million (95% UI: 9.3-9.8 million) deaths from cancer (9.5 million excluding non-melanoma skin cancer) worldwide in 2018.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisVaku77O&md5=db8d895060c7770078fec16e2d9eb816

      3. 3
        Patel, S. M.; Nagulapalli Venkata, K. C.; Bhattacharyya, P.; Sethi, G.; Bishayee, A. Potential of neem (Azadirachta indica L.) for prevention and treatment of oncologic diseases. Semin. Cancer Biol. 2016, 40â41, 100â 115, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.semcancer.2016.03.002
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        3
        Potential of neem (Azadirachta indica L.) for prevention and treatment of oncologic diseases
        Patel, Shradha M.; Nagulapalli Venkata, Kalyan C.; Bhattacharyya, Piyali; Sethi, Gautam; Bishayee, Anupam
        Seminars in Cancer Biology (2016), 40-41 (), 100-115CODEN: SECBE7; ISSN:1044-579X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Throughout time, plants have often displayed medicinal properties that have been underscored. We often derive medicines involved in treating cancer from components in plants. Azadirachta indica, commonly known as "neem", has been used to treat different ailments in many Asian countries. Due to its widespread beneficial uses, A. indica has often been referred to as "the wonder tree" or "nature's drug store". Various parts of this plant, including, leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds, roots, bark and oil, produce a large no. of phytochems. with various biol. and pharmacol. activities. The numerous biol. activities of the phytoconstituents of A. indica explain its beneficial uses for the prevention and therapy of cancer. The chemopreventive and anticancer therapeutic efficacy of A. indica fractions and compds. could be explained by multiple cellular and mol. mechanisms, including free radical scavenging, carcinogen-detoxification, DNA repair, cell cycle alteration, programmed cell death (apoptosis) and autophagy, immune surveillance, anti-inflammatory, anti-angiogenic, anti-invasive and anti-metastatic activities as well as their ability to modulate several dysregulated oncogenic signaling pathways. This article aims to present the collective and crit. anal. of multiple phytoconstituents of A. indica and their mol. mechanisms implicated in cancer chemopreventive and therapeutic effects based on published preclin. and clin. results. Current limitations and future directions of research on this medicinal plant are also critically discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xms1WktLo%253D&md5=8d3c9362632987d6aeef9029498f942d
      4. 4
        Islas, J. F.; Acosta, E.; G-Buentello, Z.; Delgado-Gallegos, J. L.; Moreno-TreviÃ±o, M. G.; Escalante, B.; Moreno-Cuevas, J. E. An overview of neem (Azadirachta indica) and its potential impact on health. J. Funct. Foods 2020, 74, 104171, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.jff.2020.104171
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        4
        An overview of Neem (Azadirachta indica) and its potential impact on health
        Islas, Jose Francisco; Acosta, Ezeiza; G-Buentello, Zuca; Delgado-Gallegos, Juan Luis; Moreno-Trevino, Maria Guadalupe; Escalante, Bruno; Moreno-Cuevas, Jorge E.
        Journal of Functional Foods (2020), 74 (), 104171CODEN: JFFOAX; ISSN:1756-4646. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Global health and medical practice seek to merge alternative medicine with evidence-based medicine for a better understanding of the metabolic process and its effects in the human body. An example is the use of complementary medicine like phytotherapy. Azadirachta indica (Neem), a tree originally from India and Myanmar, called by many "The village pharmacy" or "Divine tree" because of its many health properties. In recent times, Neem-derived exts. have been shown to work from anywhere from insect repellent, to supplements to lower inflammation, diabetic control, and even to combat cancer. Herein, we state the health benefits found in diverse compds. and exts. derived from Neem, highlighting the mechanisms and pathways in which Neem compds. produce their effects, while warning that the improper and unstandardized conditions to produce exts. can lead to health issues, particularly certain compds. might have damaging effects on the liver and kidneys.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Subapriya, R.; Nagini, S. Medicinal properties of neem leaves: A review. Curr. Med. Chem.: Anti-Cancer Agents 2005, 5, 149â 156, Â DOI: 10.2174/1568011053174828

        5
        Medicinal properties of neem leaves: a review
        Subapriya, R.; Nagini, S.
        Current Medicinal Chemistry: Anti-Cancer Agents (2005), 5 (2), 149-156CODEN: CMCACI; ISSN:1568-0118. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        A review. Azadirachta indica, commonly known as neem, has attracted worldwide prominence in recent years, owing to its wide range of medicinal properties. Neem was extensively used in Ayurveda, Unani and Homeopathic medicine and has become a cynosure of modern medicine. Neem elaborates a vast array of biol. active compds. that are chem. diverse and structurally complex. More than 140 compds. were isolated from different parts of neem. All parts of the neem tree- leaves, flowers, seeds, fruits, roots and bark were used traditionally for the treatment of inflammation, infections, fever, skin diseases and dental disorders. The medicinal utilities were described esp. for neem leaf. Neem leaf and its constituents were demonstrated to exhibit immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, antihyperglycemic, antiulcer, antimalarial, antifungal, antibacterial, antiviral, antioxidant, antimutagenic and anticarcinogenic properties. This review summarizes the wide range of pharmacol. activities of neem leaf.

      6. 6
        Hummel, H. E.; Langner, S. S.; Leithold, G.; Schmutterer, H. Neem: Unusually versatile plant genus Azadirachta with many useful and so far insufficiently exploited properties for agriculture, medicine, and industry. Commun. Agric. Appl. Biol. Sci. 2014, 79, 211â 228
        [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        6
        NEEM: UNUSUALLY VERSATILE PLANT GENUS AZADIRACHTA WITH MANY USEFUL AND SO FAR INSUFFICIENTLY EXPLOITED PROPERTIES FOR AGRICULTURE, MEDICINE, AND INDUSTRY
        Hummel H E; Langner S S; Leithold G; Schmutterer H
        Communications in agricultural and applied biological sciences (2014), 79 (2), 211-28 ISSN:1379-1176.
        Neem plants (Rutales: Meliaceae) are well known for their multitude of human benefits in various fields. Specifically well investigated are the Indian neem tree Azadirachta indica A. Juss., the Thai neem A. siamensis Val., the originally Malaysian/Philippinean neem A. excelsa (Jack) and, as a close relative, the Persian lilac, Melia azedarach. The major and most active natural products are azadirachtin, salannin, nimbin and marrangin from Azadirachta species, and azadirachtin analogues like meliantriol from Melia species. Neem fruits, leaves, bark, and roots have specific virtues. They have been traditionally exploited for a considerable part of human history and are documented in Sanskrit texts. Due to human activity in trade and travel both at land and sea, the plant species has been distributed around the globe and is cultivated in many tropical, and subtropical regions. A multitude of natural products of neem have been isolated, chemically characterized or identified, and investigated for their properties in the management of insects, Acarina, Crustacea, nematodes, bacteria, fungi, viruses and soil fertility (for reviews see Kraus, 2002; Schmutterer, 2002A; Rembold, 2002; Koul, 2004; Schmutterer and Huber, 2005; Kleeberg and Strang, 2009; Hummel et al., 2008, 2011, 2012). Neem products are virtually nontoxic, compatible with beneficial insects, pollinators and bees. They are environmentally benign, sustainable, renewable, and of a price affordable for developed countries. In conclusion, neem is a prime example of a natural resource with many beneficial applications in agriculture, human and veterinary medicine. So far, its use is practically free of resistance problems which are frustratingly prevalent in many areas of synthetic insecticide and drug development. Investigating more neem applications will increase future human welfare and health while being of general ecological benefit to the planet.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2Mbks1CrsQ%253D%253D&md5=6b0a8185f092ca4c11299c8dd0e6907f
      7. 7
        Kharwar, R. N.; Sharma, V. K.; Mishra, A.; Kumar, J.; Singh, D. K.; Verma, S. K.; Gond, S. K.; Kumar, A.; Kaushik, N.; Revuru, B.; Kusari, S. Harnessing the phytotherapeutic treasure troves of the ancient medicinal plant Azadirachta indica (neem) and associated endophytic microorganisms. Planta Med. 2020, 86, 906â 940, Â DOI: 10.1055/a-1107-9370
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        7
        Harnessing the Phytotherapeutic Treasure Troves of the Ancient Medicinal Plant Azadirachta indica (Neem) and Associated Endophytic Microorganisms
        Kharwar, Ravindra N.; Sharma, Vijay K.; Mishra, Ashish; Kumar, Jitendra; Singh, Dheeraj K.; Verma, Satish K.; Gond, Surendra K.; Kumar, Anuj; Kaushik, Nutan; Revuru, Bharadwaj; Kusari, Souvik
        Planta Medica (2020), 86 (13/14), 906-940CODEN: PLMEAA; ISSN:0032-0943. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        Azadirachta indica, commonly known as neem, is an evergreen tree of the tropics and sub-tropics native to the Indian subcontinent with demonstrated ethnomedicinal value and importance in agriculture as well as in the pharmaceutical industry. This ancient medicinal tree, often called the "wonder tree", is regarded as a chem. factory of diverse and complex compds. with a plethora of structural scaffolds that is very difficult to mimic by chem. synthesis. Such multifaceted chem. diversity leads to a fantastic repertoire of functional traits, encompassing a wide variety of biol. activity and unique modes of action against specific and generalist pathogens and pests. Until now, more than 400 compds. have been isolated from different parts of neem including important bioactive secondary metabolites such as azadirachtin, nimbidin, nimbin, nimbolide, gedunin, and many more. In addn. to its insecticidal property, the plant is also known for antimicrobial, antimalarial, antiviral, anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic, hypoglycemic, antiulcer, antifertility, anticarcinogenic, hepatoprotective, antioxidant, anxiolytic, molluscicidal, acaricidal, and antifilarial properties. Notwithstanding the chem. and biol. virtuosity of neem, it has also been extensively explored for assocd. microorganisms, esp. a class of mutualists called endophytic microorganisms (or endophytes). More than 30 compds., including neem "mimetic" compds., have been reported from endophytes harbored in the neem trees in different ecol. niches. In this review, we provide an informative and in-depth overview of the topic that can serve as a point of ref. for an understanding of the functions and applications of a medicinal plant such as neem, including assocd. endophytes, within the overall theme of phytopathol. Our review further exemplifies the already-noted current surge of interest in plant and microbial natural products for implications both within the ecol. and clin. settings, for a more secure and sustainable future.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXksVynsb0%253D&md5=ae3f5614213b0569872de57e94e7d70f
      8. 8
        Nagini, S. Neem limonoids as anticancer agents: Modulation of cancer hallmarks and oncogenic signaling. Enzymes 2014, 36, 131â 147, Â DOI: 10.1016/B978-0-12-802215-3.00007-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        8
        Neem limonoids as anticancer agents: modulation of cancer hallmarks and oncogenic signaling
        Nagini, Siddavaram
        Enzymes (2014), 36 (), 131-147CODEN: 25GLAS ISSN:. (Elsevier)
        Neem (Azadirachta indica A. Juss) is one of the most versatile medicinal plants, widely distributed in the Indian subcontinent. Neem is a rich source of limonoids that are endowed with potent medicinal properties predominantly antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer activities. Azadirachtin, gedunin, and nimbolide are more extensively investigated relative to other neem limonoids. Accumulating evidence indicates that the anticancer effects of neem limonoids are mediated through the inhibition of hallmark capabilities of cancer such as cell proliferation, apoptosis evasion, inflammation, invasion, and angiogenesis. The neem limonoids have been demonstrated to target oncogenic signaling kinases and transcription factors chiefly, NF-ÎºB, Wnt/Î²-catenin, PI3K/Akt, MAPK, and JAK/STAT signaling pathways. Neem limonoids that target multiple pathways that are aberrant in cancer are ideal candidates for cancer chemoprevention and therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1yru7rO&md5=6596df3ba46c91471d4eea739e3e0292
      9. 9
        Cohen, E.; Quistad, G. B.; Casida, J. E. Cytotoxicity of nimbolide, epoxyazadiradione and other limonoids from neem insecticide. Life Sci. 1996, 58, 1075â 1081, Â DOI: 10.1016/0024-3205(96)00061-6
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        9
        Cytotoxicity of nimbolide, epoxyazadiradione and other limonoids from neem insecticide
        Cohen, Ephraim; Quistad, Gary B.; Casida, John E.
        Life Sciences (1996), 58 (13), 1075-81CODEN: LIFSAK; ISSN:0024-3205. (Elsevier)
        Neem seed prepns. contain not only azadirachtin as the active insect antifeedant or growth regulator but also a variety of other limonoids, some of which are cytotoxic to N1E-115 neuroblastoma (mouse), 143B.TK- osteosarcoma (human) and Sf9 (insect) cultured cell lines. The most potent of these limonoids is nimbolide with an IC50 ranging from 4 to 10 Î¼M and averaging 6 Î¼M for the three cell lines. Other limonoids of decreasing potency and their av. IC50 values (Î¼M) are epoxyazadiradione 27 Î¼M, salannin 112 Î¼M, and nimbin, deacetylnimbin and azadirachtin each >200 Î¼M (practically nontoxic). Nimbolide at 10 Î¼M acts rapidly in the neuroblastoma cells to induce blebbing assocd. with disruption of plasma membranes almost instantaneously and 50% loss of cell viability within 30 min. At 5 Î¼M nimbolide, the cells become elongated and assume a neuronal shape accompanied by spikes and lamellipodia within 1-2 h followed shortly thereafter by extensive cytol. changes and vacuolization assocd. with irreversible processes leading to cell death. Calcium is apparently not involved in the cytotoxic effect since a calcium-free medium, leading to profound morphol. changes, does not alter the sensitivity to nimbolide. In contrast, epoxyazadiradione requires higher concns. and a few hours for 50% viability loss without major morphol. changes, indicating a difference in mode of action for nimbolide and epoxyazadiradione.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XhsVWrsLk%253D&md5=09405fc8e2475a4f25c71f0dd7de581e

        Nimbolide and isonimbolide
        Anitha, G.; Raj, J. Josepha Lourdu; Narasimhan, S.; Solomon, K. Anand; Rajan, S. S.
        Journal of Asian Natural Products Research (2006), 8 (5), 445-449CODEN: JANRFI; ISSN:1028-6020. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        Nimbolide 1, a potent mol. of biol. significance, was isolated. Attempts were made to cleave the ether linkage in nimbolide using boron trifluoride etherate in the presence of tetra-Bu ammonium bromide so as to generate a ring-opened structure akin to azadirachtins, which are known to possess excellent antifeedant properties. However, a novel rearranged product was envisaged during the course of the reaction, which was detd. as isonimbolide 2-a structural isomer of nimbolide through spectroscopic methods.

        Synthesis and biological activity of amide derivatives of nimbolide
        Sastry, B. S.; Babu, K. Suresh; Babu, T. Hari; Chandrasekhar, S.; Srinivas, P. V.; Saxena, A. K.; Rao, J. Madhusudana
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2006), 16 (16), 4391-4394CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Nimbolide (I), a limonoid isolated from Azadirachta indica, is the chief cytotoxic principle in Neem leaves ext. Using nimbolide as a lead compd. for anti-cancer analog design, a series of nimbolide derivs., e.g., II, have been synthesized by ring-opening of the lactone ring with amines, and evaluated for in vitro cytotoxic activity against a panel of human cancer cell lines. Out of the 10 compds. screened, three of them, including II, showed potent activity.

        Nimbolide, a constituent of Azadirachta indica, inhibits Plasmodium falciparum in culture
        Rochanakij, Sudaratana; Thebtaranonth, Yodhathai; Yenjai, Chavi; Yuthavong, Yongyuth
        Southeast Asian Journal of Tropical Medicine and Public Health (1985), 16 (1), 66-72CODEN: SJTMAK; ISSN:0125-1562.
        The terpenoid lactone nimbolide (I) [25990-37-8] inhibited P. falciparum in culture with a moderate potency. The EC50 against the parasite line K1 from Thailand was approx. 2.0 Î¼M (0.95 Î¼g/m). The EC50 of crude aq. ext. of Azadirachta indica siamensis (Sadao tree), was 115 Î¼g/mL, and of crude EtOH ext. was 5.0 Î¼g/mL. Since I is a major constituent in these exts., it could account substantially for their inhibitory activity. However, neither the crude exts. nor I showed any activity in vivo against P. berghei in the mouse either through ingestion (746 mg aq. ext., 62.5 mg EtOH ext. or 12.5 mg nimbolide/kg/day), or s.c. injection (93 mg aq. ext., 31 mg EtOH ext. or 12.5 mg I/kg/day).

        Githua, M.; Hassanali, A.; Keriko, J.; Murilla, G.; Ndungu, M.; Nyagah, G. New antitrypanosomal tetranotriterpenoids from Azadirachta indica. Afr. J. Tradit. Complement Altern. Med. 2010, 7, 207â 213
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        New antitrypanosomal tetranotriterpenoids from Azadirachta indica
        Githua, Mercy; Hassanali, Ahmed; Keriko, Joseph; Murilla, Grace; Ndungu, Mary; Nyagah, Gathu
        African Journal of Traditional, Complementary and Alternative Medicines (2010), 7 (3), 207-213CODEN: AJTCAU; ISSN:0189-6016. (African Networks on Ethnomedicines)
        Org. exts. of the leaves of Azadirachta indica A. Juss. yielded ten antitrypanosomal terpenoids. Three of these (1 - 3), are novel and are derivs. of nimbolide and nimbin. They were extd. from chloroform fraction of methanol ext. These compds. were found to exhibit strong antitrypanosomal activities against Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense with MIC values ranging of 6.9, 15.6 and 7.8 Î¼g/mL resp. and were more active than Cymerlarsan (a std. drug), which had an MIC value of 187.5 Î¼g/mL when tested against T. b. rhodesiense. The structures were elucidated by spectroscopic methods including; NMR, MS, UV and IR.

      14. 14
        Sarkar, P.; Acharyya, S.; Banerjee, A.; Patra, A.; Thankamani, K.; Koley, H.; Bag, P. K. Intracellular, biofilm-inhibitory and membrane-damaging activities of nimbolide isolated from Azadirachta indica A. Juss (Meliaceae) against meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. J. Med. Microbiol. 2016, 65, 1205â 1214, Â DOI: 10.1099/jmm.0.000343
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        14
        Intracellular, biofilm-inhibitory and membrane-damaging activities of nimbolide isolated from Azadirachta indica A. Juss (Meliaceae) against meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
        Sarkar, Prodipta; Acharyya, Saurabh; Banerjee, Anirban; Patra, Amarendra; Thankamani, Karthika; Koley, Hemanta; Bag, Prasanta K.
        Journal of Medical Microbiology (2016), 65 (10), 1205-1214CODEN: JMMIAV; ISSN:0022-2615. (Society for General Microbiology)
        Staphylococcus aureus is a leading etiol. agent of nosocomial- and community-acquired infectious diseases worldwide. The public health concern regarding staphylococcal infections is inflated by the increasing occurrence of multidrug-resistant strains, e.g. multidrug- and meticillin-resistant S. aureus (MDR MRSA). This study was designed to evaluate the intracellular killing, membrane-damaging and biofilm-inhibitory activities of nimbolide isolated from Azadirachta indica against MDR MRSA. In vitro antibacterial activity of nimbolide was detd. by performing MIC, minimal bactericidal concn. (MBC) and time-kill kinetic studies. Bacterial membrane-damaging activity was detd. by membrane perturbation and SEM (SEM) examn. Biofilm-inhibitory activities were detd. by SEM. Cellular drug accumulation and assessments of intracellular activities were performed using Vero cell culture. SEM revealed that nimbolide caused significant membrane damage and lysis of the S. aureus cells. The biofilm structure was disrupted, and the biofilm formation was greatly reduced in the presence of nimbolide as examd. by SEM. The level of accumulation of nimbolide in Vero cells incubated for 24 h is relatively higher than that of ciprofloxacin and nalidixic acid (Cc/Ce for nimbolide > ciprofloxacin and nalidixic acid). The viable no. of intracellular S. aureus was decreased [redn. of â¼2 log10 c.f.u. (mg Vero cell protein)-1] in a time-dependent manner in the presence of nimbolide (4Ã MBC) that was comparable to that of tetracycline and nalidixic acid. The significant intracellular, biofilm-inhibitory and bacterial membrane-damaging activities of nimbolide demonstrated here suggested that it has potential as an effective antibacterial agent for the treatment of severe infections caused by MDR MRSA.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitlSntb7K&md5=3d371999538ec7bacf09dd663c45d844
      15. 15
        Thakur, P. K.; Kumar, J.; Ray, D.; Anjum, F.; Hassan, I. Md. Search of potential inhibitor against New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1 from a series of antibacterial natural compounds. J. Nat. Sci. Biol. Med. 2013, 4, 51â 56, Â DOI: 10.4103/0976-9668.107260
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        15
        Search of potential inhibitor against New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1 from a series of antibacterial natural compounds
        Thakur, Prasoon Kumar; Kumar, Jitender; Ray, Divya; Anjum, Farah; Hassan, Md. Imtaiyaz
        Journal of Natural Science, Biology and Medicine (2013), 4 (1), 51-56CODEN: JNSBAD; ISSN:2229-7707. (Medknow Publications and Media Pvt. Ltd.)
        New Delhi metallo-Î²-lactamase-1 (NDM-1)-producing Gram-neg. bacteria are today's major worldwide health concern. The enzyme NDM-1 provides bacterial resistance by its hydrolytic activity against the Î²-lactam ring of antibiotics. Inhibition of NDM-1 may prevent the hydrolysis of Î²-lactam ring of the antibiotics, and therefore, plays an important role against antibacterial resistance. Materials and Methods: Here we made an attempt to design suitable inhibitors against NDM-1 from different natural antibacterial compds. using mol. docking approach. Results: We obsd. that natural compds. such as Nimbolide and Isomargololone are showing an appreciable IC50 value as well as significant binding energy value for NDM-1. We further obsd. these compds. showing better affinity to NDM-1 on comparison with 14 Î²-lactam antibiotics. Conclusion: Finally, our study provides a platform for the development of a potent inhibitor of NDM-1, which may be considered as a potential drug candidate against bacterial resistance.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjvV2iu7Y%253D&md5=c8f4650d012ed88b86d833fa1942a0a6

        Vora, J.; Patel, S.; Sinha, S.; Sharma, S.; Srivastava, A.; Chhabria, M.; Shrivastava, N. Molecular docking, QSAR and ADMET based mining of natural compounds against prime targets of HIV. J. Biomol. Struct. Dyn. 2019, 37, 131â 146, Â DOI: 10.1080/07391102.2017.1420489
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        16
        Molecular docking, QSAR and ADMET based mining of natural compounds against prime targets of HIV
        Vora, Jaykant; Patel, Shivani; Sinha, Sonam; Sharma, Sonal; Srivastava, Anshu; Chhabria, Mahesh; Shrivastava, Neeta
        Journal of Biomolecular Structure and Dynamics (2019), 37 (1), 131-146CODEN: JBSDD6; ISSN:0739-1102. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        AIDS is one of the multifaceted diseases and this underlying complexity hampers its complete cure. The toxicity of existing drugs and emergence of multidrug-resistant virus makes the treatment worse. Development of effective, safe and low-cost anti-HIV drugs is among the top global priority. Exploration of natural resources may give ray of hope to develop new anti-HIV leads. Among the various therapeutic targets for HIV treatment, reverse transcriptase, protease, integrase, GP120, and RNase are the prime focus. In the present study, we predicted potential plant-derived natural mols. for HIV treatment using computational approach, i.e. mol. docking, quant. structure activity relationship (QSAR), and ADMET studies. Receptor-ligand binding studies were performed using three different software for precise prediction - Discovery studio 4.0, Schrodinger and Molegrow virtual docker. Docking scores revealed that Mulberrosides, Anolignans, Curcumin and Chebulic acid are promising candidates that bind with multi targets of HIV, while Neo-andrographolide, Nimbolide and Punigluconin were target-specific candidates. Subsequently, QSAR was performed using biol. proved compds. which predicted the biol. activity of compds. We identified Anolignans, Curcumin, Mulberrosides, Chebulic acid and Neo-andrographolide as potential natural mols. for HIV treatment from results of mol. docking and 3D-QSAR. In silico ADMET studies showed drug-likeness of these lead mols. Structure similarities of identified lead mols. were compared with identified marketed drugs by superimposing both the mols. Using in silico studies, we have identified few best fit mols. of natural origin against identified targets which may give new drugs to combat HIV infection after wet lab validation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitVWqt7Y%253D&md5=f01b6e6fb4acd43fa1bd7759cc33234f
      17. 17
        Diddi, S.; Bale, S.; Pulivendala, G.; Godugu, C. Nimbolide ameliorates fibrosis and inflammation in experimental murine model of bleomycin-induced scleroderma. Inflammopharmacology 2019, 27, 139â 149, Â DOI: 10.1007/s10787-018-0527-4
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        17
        Nimbolide ameliorates fibrosis and inflammation in experimental murine model of bleomycin-induced scleroderma
        Diddi, Snehalatha; Bale, Swarna; Pulivendala, Gauthami; Godugu, Chandraiah
        Inflammopharmacology (2019), 27 (1), 139-149CODEN: IAOAES; ISSN:0925-4692. (Birkhaeuser Basel)
        Objective: Our current study is aimed at demonstrating the antifibrotic and anti-inflammatory potential of nimbolide, a triterpene derived from Indian traditional plant neem, in a murine model of Bleomycin-induced scleroderma. Methods: Male C57BL/6 mice were administered with Bleomycin injections s.c., daily for 28 days, at a const. site on the dorsum of the mice. Treatment with nimbolide lasted from day 1 to day 28. At the time of study termination, the injected sites were collected and stored suitably to conduct further mol. expts. and protein expression studies. Results and conclusion: The results of our study show that nimbolide can significantly intervene in the TGF-Î²/Smad signaling axis and the consequent EMT process, thus attenuating deposition of extracellular matrix. Nimbolide also profoundly caused the regression of established inflammation-driven fibrosis, thus demonstrating both antifibrotic and anti-inflammatory activities. Another commendable finding of this study is that nimbolide was able to decrease the levels of LOXL2, a collagen cross-linker, which is aberrantly expressed in scleroderma. Although further mechanistic studies are required, our study displays nimbolide for the first time as a potent antifibrotic agent which can be used as a pharmacol. intervention for the treatment of scleroderma.

        Prashanth Goud, M.; Bale, S.; Pulivendala, G.; Godugu, C. Therapeutic effects of nimbolide, an autophagy regulator, in ameliorating pulmonary fibrosis through attenuation of TGF-Î²1 driven epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition. Int.         18
        Therapeutic effects of Nimbolide, an autophagy regulator, in ameliorating pulmonary fibrosis through attenuation of TGF-gamma1 driven epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition
        Prashanth Goud, M.; Bale, Swarna; Pulivendala, Gauthami; Godugu, Chandraiah
        International Immunopharmacology (2019), 75 (), 105755CODEN: IINMBA; ISSN:1567-5769. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Pulmonary fibrosis is an irreversible lung disorder with predictable decline in lung function leading to respiratory insufficiency. Incidence of pulmonary fibrosis has been apparently increasing worldwide. Though etiol. of this disease remains unclear, potential roles of infection, disordered cell biol., genetic influence etc. have been proposed. Pirfenidone and nintedanib are the only two US FDA approved drugs to treat pulmonary fibrosis. Autophagy is a catabolic intracellular pathway that plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis, which is involved in many disorders including fibrotic diseases. The present study investigated the role of Nimbolide, an important active constituent of Neem in TGF-gamma1 induced in vitro and bleomycin induced in vivo model of pulmonary fibrosis, with a slight emphasis on regulation of fibrosis related autophagy. Protein expression studies showed significant redn. in mesenchymal, fibrotic markers and a substantial up regulation of epithelial markers upon treatment with Nimbolide. Nimbolide regulated autophagy signaling by dampening LC-3 and p-62 expression and increasing Beclin 1 expression as evidenced by immunohistochem. and confocal microscopy. Our study demonstrates Nimbolide as a potent anti-fibrotic agent and its ability to regulate fibrosis assocd. autophagy.

        Annaldas, S.; Saifi, M. A.; Khurana, A.; Godugu, C. Nimbolide ameliorates unilateral ureteral obstruction-induced renal fibrosis by inhibition of TGF-beta and EMT/Slug signalling. Mol. Immunol. 2019, 112, 247â 255, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.molimm.2019.06.003
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        19
        Nimbolide ameliorates unilateral ureteral obstruction-induced renal fibrosis by inhibition of TGF-Î² and EMT/Slug signalling
        Annaldas, Shivaraju; Saifi, Mohd Aslam; Khurana, Amit; Godugu, Chandraiah
        Molecular Immunology (2019), 112 (), 247-255CODEN: MOIMD5; ISSN:0161-5890. (Elsevier)
        Chronic kidney disease (CKD) involves interstitial fibrosis as an underlying pathol. process assocd. with compromised renal function irresp. of etiol. cause of the injury. The transforming growth factor-Î² (TGF-Î²) plays a pivotal role in progression of renal fibrosis. TGF-Î² transduces its downstream signaling by phosphorylation of smad2/3 and also regulates epithelial-mesenchymal-transition (EMT), a program centrally involved in activation of fibroblasts. Renal fibrosis was induced in Swiss albino mice by unilateral ureteral obstruction of animals. Kidney tissues were evaluated for fibrotic protein expression by western blot and immunohistochem. The administration of nimbolide (NB) to UUO animals reduced the oxidative stress, expression of ECM proteins, TGF-Î², p-smad and EMT program. Further, NB administration also improved histoarchitecture of obstructed kidney and reduced the collagen deposition in kidney. Our results provided compelling evidence to support antifibrotic activity of NB by redn. in oxidative stress, TGF-Î², and EMT program in fibrotic kidney. The administration of NB in animals blunted the UUO-induced renal injury, inflammation and reduced fibrogenesis in obstructed kidney.

        Nimbolide Inhibits Nuclear Factor-ÎºB Pathway in Intestinal Epithelial Cells and Macrophages and Alleviates Experimental Colitis in Mice
        Seo, Ji Yeon; Lee, Changhyun; Hwang, Sung Wook; Chun, Jaeyoung; Im, Jong Pil; Kim, Joo Sung
        Phytotherapy Research (2016), 30 (10), 1605-1614CODEN: PHYREH; ISSN:0951-418X. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        Nimbolide is a limonoid extd. from neem tree (Azadirachta indica) that has antiinflammatory properties. The effect of nimbolide on the nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-ÎºB) pathway in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs), macrophages and in murine colitis models was investigated. The IEC COLO 205, the murine macrophage cell line RAW 264.7, and peritoneal macrophages from interleukin-10-deficient (IL-10-/-) mice were preconditioned with nimbolide and then stimulated with tumor necrosis factor-Î± (TNF-Î±) or lipopolysaccharide. Dextran sulfate sodium-induced acute colitis model and chronic colitis model in IL-10-/- mice were used for in vivo expts. Nimbolide significantly suppressed the expression of inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, IL-12, and TNF-Î±) and inhibited the phosphorylation of IÎºBÎ± and the DNA-binding affinity of NF-ÎºB in IECs and macrophages. Nimbolide ameliorated wt. loss, colon shortening, disease activity index score, and histol. scores in dextran sulfate sodium colitis. It also improved histopathol. scores in the chronic colitis of IL-10-/- mice. Staining for phosphorylated IÎºBÎ± was significantly decreased in the colon tissue after treatment with nimbolide in both models. Nimbolide inhibits NF-ÎºB signaling in IECs and macrophages and ameliorates exptl. colitis in mice. These results suggest nimbolide could be a potentially new treatment for inflammatory bowel disease. Copyright Â© 2016 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

        Bansod, S.; Aslam Saifi, M.; Khurana, A.; Godugu, C. Nimbolide abrogates cerulein-induced chronic pancreatitis by modulating beta-catenin/Smad in a sirtuin-dependent way. Pharmacol. Res. 2020, 156, 104756, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.phrs.2020.104756
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        21
        Nimbolide abrogates cerulein-induced chronic pancreatitis by modulating Î²-catenin/Smad in a sirtuin-dependent way
        Bansod, Sapana; Aslam Saifi, Mohd.; Khurana, Amit; Godugu, Chandraiah
        Pharmacological Research (2020), 156 (), 104756CODEN: PHMREP; ISSN:1043-6618. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is one of the leading causes of mortality worldwide with no clin. approved therapeutic interventions. The present study was designed to investigate the protective effect of nimbolide (NB), an active constituent of neem tree (Azadirachta indica), by targeting Î²-catenin/Smad/SIRT1 in caerulein-induced CP model. The effects of NB was investigated on caerulein (50 Î¼g/kg/h*6 exposures /day, 3 days a week for 3 wk) induced CP in mice. Amylase and lipase activity were measured and histopathol. evaluation was performed. Collagen deposition in the pancreatic tissue was estd. by hydroxyproline assay, and collagen specific staining picrosirius red and Masson's trichrome. Caerulein-induced CP was significantly controlled by NB treatment, as shown by the downregulation of Î²-catenin/Smad signaling in a SIRT1 dependent manner. NB treatment significantly decreased Î±-SMA, MMP-2, collagen1a, fibronectin, TGF-Î²1, p-Smad-2/3 expression and extracellular matrix (ECM) deposition in pancreatic tissue. However, the protective effects of NB on caerulein-induced CP were undermined by nicotinamide (NMD) or splitomicin, sirtuin 1 (SIRT1) inhibitors treatment. NB treatment modulated protein expression by activating SIRT1 and decreasing the expression of Î²-catenin/Smad proteins in CP mice. However, the expression of SIRT1 in pancreatic tissue was elevated by NB treatment and it was decreased by NMD or splitomicin treatment. In summary, our results strongly suggest that NB exerted promising protective effects in caerulein-induced CP model by inhibiting Î²-catenin/Smad in a sirtuin-dependent manner, which could be attributed to its anti-inflammatory and antifibrotic effects. Our study suggests that NB could be an effective therapeutic intervention for the treatment of CP.

        Evaluation of antiarthritic activity of nimbolide against Freund's adjuvant induced arthritis in rats
        Cui, Xin; Wang, Ruijing; Bian, Peimin; Wu, Qingke; Seshadri, Vidya Devanatha Desikan; Liu, Lun
        Artificial Cells, Nanomedicine, and Biotechnology (2019), 47 (1), 3391-3398CODEN: ACNBCI; ISSN:2169-141X. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        Nimbolide, a triterpenoid isolated from flower of neem tree possess various therapeutic properties. The objective of the study was to assess the anti-arthritic activity of nimbolide in arthritis induced rats. Nimbolide (20 mg/kg per day) was given orally to arthritic rats induced with Complete Freund's Adjuvant and changes inpaw vol., body wt., organ indexes (thymus and spleen), arthritic score, biochem. parameters and proinflammatory cytokines levels were detd. Histopathol. anal. was also performed. Western blot anal. was also performed. Rats treated with nimbolide displayed marked redn. in arthritic score, organ indexes, vol. of paw, edema formation, along with substantial enhancement in body wt. Histopathol. findings showed significant redn. in destruction of joints and inflammation following nimbolide treatment. The protective action of arthritic rats treated with nimbolide was also substantiated by mol. and biochem. studies. The results of the study show that nimbolide treatment has markedly enhanced health and reduced inflammation via lessening the proinflammatory cytokines expression in arthritic rats. Hence, nimbolide may be used as a potent therapeutic drug in treating rheumatoid arthritis.

      23. 23
        Pooladanda, V.; Thatikonda, S.; Bale, S.; Pattnaik, B.; Sigalapalli, D. K.; Bathini, N. B.; Singh, S. B.; Godugu, C. Nimbolide protects against endotoxin-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome by inhibiting TNF-Î± mediated NF-ÎºB and HDAC-3 nuclear translocation. Cell Death Dis. 2019, 10, 81, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41419-018-1247-9
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        23
        Nimbolide protects against endotoxin-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome by inhibiting TNF-Î± mediated NF-ÎºB and HDAC-3 nuclear translocation
        Pooladanda Venkatesh; Thatikonda Sowjanya; Bale Swarna; Singh Shashi Bala; Godugu Chandraiah; Pattnaik Bijay; Sigalapalli Dilep Kumar; Bathini Nagendra Babu
        Cell death & disease (2019), 10 (2), 81 ISSN:.
        Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by an excessive acute inflammatory response in lung parenchyma, which ultimately leads to refractory hypoxemia. One of the earliest abnormalities seen in lung injury is the elevated levels of inflammatory cytokines, among them, the soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF-Î±) has a key role, which exerts cytotoxicity in epithelial and endothelial cells thus exacerbates edema. The bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) was used both in vitro (RAW 264.7, THP-1, MLE-12, A549, and BEAS-2B) and in vivo (C57BL/6 mice), as it activates a plethora of overlapping inflammatory signaling pathways involved in ARDS. Nimbolide is a chemical constituent of Azadirachta indica, which contains multiple biological properties, while its role in ARDS is elusive. Herein, we have investigated the protective effects of nimbolide in abrogating the complications associated with ARDS. We showed that nimbolide markedly suppressed the nitrosative-oxidative stress, inflammatory cytokines, and chemokines expression by suppressing iNOS, myeloperoxidase, and nitrotyrosine expression. Moreover, nimbolide mitigated the migration of neutrophils and mast cells whilst normalizing the LPS-induced hypothermia. Also, nimbolide modulated the expression of epigenetic regulators with multiple HDAC inhibitory activity by suppressing the nuclear translocation of NF-ÎºB and HDAC-3. We extended our studies using molecular docking studies, which demonstrated a strong interaction between nimbolide and TNF-Î±. Additionally, we showed that treatment with nimbolide increased GSH, Nrf-2, SOD-1, and HO-1 protein expression; concomitantly abrogated the LPS-triggered TNF-Î±, p38 MAPK, mTOR, and GSK-3Î² protein expression. Collectively, these results indicate that TNF-Î±-regulated NF-ÎºB and HDAC-3 crosstalk was ameliorated by nimbolide with promising anti-nitrosative, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties in LPS-induced ARDS.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Nimbolide attenuate the lipid accumulation, oxidative stress and antioxidant in primary hepatocytes
        Alshammari, Ghedeir M.; Balakrishnan, Aristatile; Chinnasamy, Thirunavukkarasu
        Molecular Biology Reports (2017), 44 (6), 463-474CODEN: MLBRBU; ISSN:0301-4851. (Springer)
        Nimbolide is a bioactive compd. found in Azadirachta indica. This work was devised to investigate the potential effects of nimbolide on intracellular lipid deposition and its assocd. redox modulation in primary hepatocytes (Heps). Lipid accumulation was induced in Heps by supplementing 1 mM oleic acid for 24 h which was marked by significant accumulation of lipids. The results demonstrated that nimbolide can decrease intracellular cholesterol, free fatty acids and triglycerides. Nimbolide may also improve hepatocytes function through its antioxidant effects by inhibiting oxidative DNA damage and lipid peroxidn. by curtailing the reactive oxygen species levels. Further it also restore the mitochondrial potential, improving the endogenous antioxidant levels such as GSH and antioxidant enzyme activities. Nimbolide increased (P < 0.05) liver X receptor-Î± (LXRÎ±), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-Î³ (PPARÎ³) and sterol regulatory element-binding protein-1c (SREBP1c) gene expression in Heps. The biol. significance of nimbolide may involve hypolipidemic effect, lipid peroxidn. inhibition, DNA damage inhibition, ROS inhibition, restoring mitochondrial function, increases in GSH and SOD & CAT activities, and direct regulation of LXRÎ±, PPARÎ³ and SREBP1c gene expression. Nimbolide may be used as effective lipid lowering compd. and lipid deposition-induced Heps changes.

      26. 26
        Omiecinski, C. J.; Vanden Heuvel, J. P.; Perdew, G. H.; Peters, J. M. Xenobiotic metabolism, disposition, and regulation by receptors: from biochemical phenomenon to predictors of major toxicities. Toxicol. Sci. 2011, 120, S49â S75, Â DOI: 10.1093/toxsci/kfq338
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        26
        Xenobiotic metabolism, disposition, and regulation by receptors: from biochemical phenomenon to predictors of major toxicities
        Omiecinski, Curtis J.; Vanden Heuvel, John P.; Perdew, Gary H.; Peters, Jeffrey M.
        Toxicological Sciences (2011), 120 (S1), S49-S75CODEN: TOSCF2; ISSN:1096-6080. (Oxford University Press)
        A review. To commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Society of Toxicol., this special edition article reviews the history and current scope of xenobiotic metab. and transport, with special emphasis on the discoveries and impact of selected "xenobiotic receptors. " This overall research realm has witnessed dynamic development in the past 50 years, and several of the key milestone events that mark the impressive progress in these areas of toxicol. sciences are highlighted. From the initial observations regarding aspects of drug metab. dating from the mid- to late 1800's, the area of biotransformation research witnessed seminal discoveries in the mid-1900's and onward that are remarkable in retrospect, including the discovery and characterization of the phase I monooxygenases, the cytochrome P450s. Further research uncovered many aspects of the biochem. of xenobiotic metab., expanding to phase II conjugation and phase III xenobiotic transport. This led to hallmark developments involving integration of genomic technologies to elucidate the basis for interindividual differences in response to xenobiotic exposures and discovery of nuclear and sol. receptor families that selectively "sense" the chem. milieu of the mammalian cell and orchestrate compensatory changes in gene expression programming to accommodate complex xenobiotic exposures. This review will briefly summarize these developments and investigate the expanding roles of xenobiotic receptor biol. in the underlying basis of toxicol. response to chem. agents.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXis1Cgs7Y%253D&md5=6e530678dc2bb6c3754268bbecb1560e
      27. 27
        Priyadarsini, R. V.; Manikandan, P.; Kumar, G. H.; Nagini, S. The neem limonoids azadirachtin and nimbolide inhibit hamster cheek pouch carcinogenesis by modulating xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes, DNA damage, antioxidants, invasion and angiogenesis. Free Radical Res. 2009, 43, 492â 504, Â DOI: 10.1080/10715760902870637
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        27
        The neem limonoids azadirachtin and nimbolide inhibit hamster cheek pouch carcinogenesis by modulating xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes, DNA damage, antioxidants, invasion and angiogenesis
        Priyadarsini, Ramamurthi Vidya; Manikandan, Palrasu; Kumar, Gurram Harish; Nagini, Siddavaram
        Free Radical Research (2009), 43 (5), 492-504CODEN: FRARER; ISSN:1071-5762. (Informa Healthcare)
        The neem tree has attracted considerable research attention as a rich source of limonoids that have potent antioxidant and anti-cancer properties. The present study was designed to evaluate the chemopreventive potential of the neem limonoids azadirachtin and nimbolide based on in vitro antioxidant assays and in vivo inhibitory effects on 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA)-induced hamster buccal pouch (HBP) carcinogenesis. Both azadirachtin and nimbolide exhibited concn.-dependent anti-radical scavenging activity and reductive potential in the order: nimbolide > azadirachtin > ascorbate. Administration of both azadirachtin and nimbolide inhibited the development of DMBA-induced HBP carcinomas by influencing multiple mechanisms including prevention of procarcinogen activation and oxidative DNA damage, upregulation of antioxidant and carcinogen detoxification enzymes and inhibition of tumor invasion and angiogenesis. On a comparative basis, nimbolide was found to be a more potent antioxidant and chemopreventive agent and offers promise as a candidate agent in multitargeted prevention and treatment of cancer.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvFKhs7g%253D&md5=ba185fa75f8732a90a05047c44116cdb
      28. 28
        Sritanaudomchai, H.; Kusamran, T.; Kuakulkiat, W.; Bunyapraphatsara, N.; Hiransalee, A.; Tepsuwan, A.; Kusamran, W. R. Quinone reductase inducers in Azadirachta indica A. Juss flowers, and their mechanisms of action. Asian Pac. J. Cancer Prev. 2005, 6, 263â 269
        [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        28
        Quinone reductase inducers in Azadirachta indica A. Juss flowers, and their mechanisms of action
        Sritanaudomchai Hathaitip; Kusamran Thanit; Kuakulkiat Worapun; Bunyapraphatsara Nuntavan; Hiransalee Ankana; Tepsuwan Anong; Kusamran Wannee R
        Asian Pacific journal of cancer prevention : APJCP (2005), 6 (3), 263-9 ISSN:1513-7368.
        We have previously shown that the flowers of neem tree (Azadirachta indica A. Juss, family Meliaceae), Thai variety, strongly induced the activity of glutathione S-transferase (GST) while resulting in a significant reduction in the activities of some cytochrome P(450)-dependent monooxygenases in rat liver, and possess cancer chemopreventive potential against chemically-induced mammary gland and liver carcinogenesis in rats. In the present study, 2 chemicals possessing strong QR inducing activity were fractionated from neem flowers using a bioassay based on the induction of QR activity in mouse hepatoma Hepa 1c1c7 cultured cells. Spectroscopic characteristics revealed that these compounds were nimbolide and chlorophylls, having CD (concentration required to double QR specific activity) values of 0.16 and 3.8 mug/ml, respectively. Nimbolide is a known constituent of neem leaves, but was found for the first time here in the flowers. Both nimbolide and chlorophylls strongly enhanced the level of QR mRNA in Hepa 1c1c7 cells, as monitored by northern blot hybridization, indicating that the mechanism by which these constituents of neem flowers induced QR activity is the induction of QR gene expression. These findings may have implication on cancer chemopreventive potential of neem flowers in experimental rats previously reported.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2MrlvFGksg%253D%253D&md5=af625dd87148d6c7fa312a260174dc29
      29. 29
        Manikandan, P.; Anandan, R.; Nagini, S. Evaluation of Azadirachta indica leaf fractions for in vitro antioxidant potential and protective effects against H2O2-induced oxidative damage to pBR322 DNA and red blood cells. J. Agric. Food Chem. 2009, 57, 6990â 6996, Â DOI: 10.1021/jf901351n
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        29
        Evaluation of Azadirachta indica Leaf Fractions for in Vitro Antioxidant Potential and Protective Effects against H2O2-Induced Oxidative Damage to pBR322 DNA and Red Blood Cells
        Manikandan, P.; Anandan, R.; Nagini, S.
        Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry (2009), 57 (15), 6990-6996CODEN: JAFCAU; ISSN:0021-8561. (American Chemical Society)
        We evaluated the protective effects of subfractions of the Et acetate fraction (EAF) and the methanolic fraction (MF) from the crude ethanolic ext. (CEE) of Azadirachta indica A. Juss (neem) leaves against various free radicals and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)-induced oxidative damage to red blood cells (RBCs) and pBR322 DNA. Neem leaf fractions reduced DPPHÂ·, ABTSÂ·+, superoxide (OÂ·-), hydroxyl (OHÂ·), and nitric oxide radicals to nonradical forms in a concn.-dependent manner. Treatment with the benzene insol. fraction from EAF (EBIF), the chloroform insol. fraction from EAF (ECIF), the chloroform insol. fraction from MF (MCIF), and the Et acetate insol. fraction from MF (MEIF) significantly mitigated H2O2-induced oxidative damage to RBCs and pBR322 DNA. Although we found low in vitro free radical scavenging activity for the benzene insol. fraction from EAF (EBSF), the chloroform sol. fraction from EAF (ECSF), the chloroform sol. fraction from MF (MCSF), and the Et acetate sol. fraction from MF (MESF), these fractions showed no effect on H2O2-induced lipid peroxidn. and pBR322 DNA damage. High-performance liq. chromatog. (HPLC) and TLC-Iatroscan anal. revealed that the greater efficacy of EBIF, ECIF, MCIF, and MEIF may be due to the presence of more polar compds. such as nimbolide and quercetin. Our studies suggest that the antioxidant and protective effects of active neem leaf fractions against H2O2-induced lipid peroxidn. and pBR322 DNA damage can be attributed to their ability to inhibit various free radicals.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXot1egsLw%253D&md5=03b0ba26aae2ee6ac5b23b4e3c2e9d33

        Ahmad, M. F.; Ansari, M. O.; Jameel, S.; Wani, A. L.; Parveen, N.; Siddique, H. R.; Shadab, G. G. H. A. Protective role of nimbolide against chemotherapeutic drug hydroxyurea induced genetic and oxidative damage in an animal model. Environ. Toxicol. Pharmacol. 2018, 60, 91â 99, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.etap.2018.04.006
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        30
        Protective role of nimbolide against chemotherapeutic drug hydroxyurea induced genetic and oxidative damage in an animal model
        Ahmad, Md. Fahim; Ansari, Mohd. Owais; Jameel, Sana; Wani, Ab Latif; Parveen, Nuzhat; Siddique, Hifzur R.; Shadab, G. G. H. A.
        Environmental Toxicology and Pharmacology (2018), 60 (), 91-99CODEN: ETOPFR; ISSN:1382-6689. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Nimbolide is known to be an antioxidant found in neem plant. Hydroxyurea is a medication frequently used in sickle-cell disease, different cancers and HIV infection. The present study aimed to evaluate the adverse effect of HU and possible amelioration by nimbolide in Wistar rats. To test the authors' hypothesis, the authors performed genotoxicity tests, biochem. assays, and histopathol. studies. The authors obsd. that HU caused higher levels of genotoxicity in the treated animals. The obsd. genetic and oxidative damage might be due to the presence of reactive species as HU increased the level of the malondialdehyde-a biomarker of oxidative damage. Interestingly, co-treatment of animals with HU and nimbolide showed a lower level of damage. The authors conclude that nimbolide significantly protects the cells from the adverse effect of HU and could be considered as a potential adjuvant for the patients under HU therapy.

      31. 31
        Shin, S. S.; Hwang, B.; Muhammad, K.; Gho, Y.; Song, J. H.; Kim, W. J.; Kim, G.; Moon, S. K. Nimbolide represses the proliferation, migration, and invasion of bladder carcinoma cells via Chk2-mediated G2/M phase cell cycle arrest, altered signaling pathways, and reduced transcription factors-associated MMP-9 expression. Evid. Based Complement Alternat. Med. 2019, 2019, 3753587, Â DOI: 10.1155/2019/3753587
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        31
        Nimbolide Represses the Proliferation, Migration, and Invasion of Bladder Carcinoma Cells via Chk2-Mediated G2/M Phase Cell Cycle Arrest, Altered Signaling Pathways, and Reduced Transcription Factors-Associated MMP-9 Expression
        Shin Seung-Shick; Hwang Byungdoo; Gho Yujeong; Song Jun-Hui; Moon Sung-Kwon; Muhammad Kashif; Kim Gonhyung; Kim Wun-Jae
        Evidence-based complementary and alternative medicine : eCAM (2019), 2019 (), 3753587 ISSN:1741-427X.
        Nimbolide, an active chemical constituent of Azadirachta indica, reportedly has several physiological effects. Here, we assessed novel anticancer effects of nimbolide against bladder cancer EJ and 5637 cells. Nimbolide treatment inhibited the proliferation of both bladder cancer cell lines with an IC50 value of 3 Î¼M. Treatment of cells with nimbolide induced G2/M phase cell cycle arrest via both Chk2-Cdc25C-Cdc2/cyclin B1-Wee1 pathway and Chk2-p21WAF1-Cdc2/cyclin B1-Wee1 pathway. Nimbolide increased JNK phosphorylation and decreased p38MAPK and AKT phosphorylation. Additionally, nimbolide impeded both wound healing migration and invasion abilities by suppressing matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) activity. Finally, nimbolide repressed the binding activity of NF-ÎºB, Sp-1, and AP-1 motifs, which are key transcription factors for MMP-9 activity regulation. Overall, our study indicates that nimbolide is a potential chemotherapeutic agent for bladder cancer.

        Elumalai, P.; Gunadharini, D. N.; Senthilkumar, K.; Banudevi, S.; Arunkumar, R.; Benson, C. S.; Sharmila, G.; Arunakaran, J. Induction of apoptosis in human breast cancer cells by nimbolide through extrinsic and intrinsic pathway. Toxicol. Lett. 2012, 215, 131â 142, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.toxlet.2012.10.008
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
